articles.headline: Political Divide Splits Relationships — and Thanksgiving, Too
articles.snippet: Families around the country are facing, or even skipping, uncomfortable holidays as the election’s repercussions enter people’s lives.
articles.abstract: Families around the country are facing, or even skipping, uncomfortable holidays as the election’s repercussions enter people’s lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Matthew Horn, a software engineer from Boulder, Colo., canceled Christmas plans with his family in Texas. Nancy Sundin, a social worker in Spokane, Wash., has called off Thanksgiving with her mother and brother. Ruth Dorancy, a software designer in Chicago, decided to move her wedding so that her fiancé’s grandmother and aunt, strong Trump supporters from Florida, could not attend.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: Snapchat’s Parent Files for a Stock Offering
articles.snippet: The confidential filing by Snap Inc. might allow the social network company to hold an offering as soon as March.
articles.abstract: The confidential filing by Snap Inc. might allow the social network company to hold an offering as soon as March.
articles.lead_paragraph: The clock has started for one of the most eagerly awaited market debuts of 2017: that of Snapchat, the popular messaging service.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Katie Benner

articles.headline: What’s Organic? A Debate Over Dirt May Boil Down to Turf
articles.snippet: With investment up in hydroponic and aquaponic systems that grow plants without soil, the question rages over whether the produce can be labeled organic.
articles.abstract: With investment up in hydroponic and aquaponic systems that grow plants without soil, the question rages over whether the produce can be labeled organic.
articles.lead_paragraph: If a fruit or vegetable isn’t grown in dirt, can it be organic?

articles.headline: William Ackman’s 2016 Fortune: Down, but Far From Out
articles.snippet: The silver-haired hedge fund billionaire is on pace to hand investors a second year of steep losses, but they are counting on his knack for turning things around.
articles.abstract: The silver-haired hedge fund billionaire is on pace to hand investors a second year of steep losses, but they are counting on his knack for turning things around.
articles.lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman is a big-moneyed, swaggering hedge fund manager with a long list of accomplishments.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Megyn Kelly’s Cautionary Tale of Crossing Donald Trump
articles.snippet: While discussing her new book, the Fox News anchor describes her initial run-in with Donald J. Trump as “prescient” and warns fellow journalists to remain vigilant while covering the Trump White House.
articles.abstract: While discussing her new book, the Fox News anchor describes her initial run-in with Donald J. Trump as “prescient” and warns fellow journalists to remain vigilant while covering the Trump White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly has spent the better part of the last year living in the main gladiator pit of 2016, becoming as much a target for Donald J. Trump as any of his opponents and emerging as a pivotal figure in the forced resignation of the Fox News Channel chairman Roger Ailes, whom she accused of sexual harassment.

articles.headline: Social Media’s Globe-Shaking Power
articles.snippet: The election of Donald J. Trump is perhaps the starkest illustration yet that social networks are helping to rewire human society.
articles.abstract: The election of Donald J. Trump is perhaps the starkest illustration yet that social networks are helping to rewire human society.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the technology industry came to grips in the last week with the reality of a presidential election that did not go its way, many in Silicon Valley landed on the idea that widespread misinformation spread online was a primary factor in the race’s outcome.

articles.headline: Syrian President Calls Donald Trump a ‘Natural Ally’ in Fight Against Terrorism
articles.snippet: Bashar al-Assad also predicted that “opposing forces” in the U.S. government and criticism from the news media could affect Mr. Trump’s actions.
articles.abstract: Bashar al-Assad also predicted that “opposing forces” in the U.S. government and criticism from the news media could affect Mr. Trump’s actions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, condemned by the Obama administration and much of the West for waging a brutal war of suppression against Islamist opponents in his country, said this week that President-elect Donald J. Trump could be a “natural ally” in the fight against terrorism. The comment underscored the degree to which the new administration’s approach could reverse central tenets of American foreign policy.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
